title: What would be that one technology that has impacted the world to the greatest extent? - Quora

response.answer_text: Tapping stones together. Humanity seems obsessed with intricacy, and mistakenly equate it with “world changing”. A nuke, no matter how powerful, is simply a spear that creates a small sun. Writing, for all it's complexity, is simply cave-man finger painting evolved. The wheel is simply overrated in it's effect. Not only did the progenitors of Native Americans not have the wheel, the Mayan, Incan and Aztec Empires built, well, empires without it. Just because the empires of Europe and Asia weren't tough enough to do so without the wheel doesn't make it “world changing”. It was Eurasia and Africa changing. That just makes the wheel a glorified crutch. Technology is defined by Merriam-Webster as 1(b)- a capability given by the practical application of knowledge. Our capability for advancement as a species started by tapping certain stones together to make tools and fire. Without the ability to hunt for the extra protein needed to build our big brains, or grind grains and other plants to better access the sugars to fuel our big brains, or the ability to cook our food to better take advantage of our joke of a digestive system, we would still be running from lions on the savannah. Without tapping and shaping stones, nothing we have today would exist because we likely wouldn't exist in our current form.

In my humble opinion, everything civilization has achieved goes back to a singular invention by a genius who invented the wheel. Imagine what the world would have been like without it. The wheel helped move whole civilizations, gave rise to faster transportation and a means to move goods to market. The wheel led to more efficiency, including the ability to wage war in distant lands, haul back booty to the conqueror and accumulate wealth and power. Of course, there are drawbacks.

The wheel. The fire changed the individual village experience, the wheel made this experience global. We could harness animal power before that but the wheel allowed the easier movement of goods without animals (a hand cart) and even greater with animals. A wagon can carry items larger than any one animal can carry by allowing teams of animals to pull a single wagon. Sure, there’s boats but how do you reach inland easily where there’s no rivers? It allowed people to move around the world easily, allowing them to escape war, disease, pestilence and famine. Generations of communities have loaded up what they owned into wheeled vehicles and moved. Can you imagine trade without carts using wheels or how war would have been much different without the chariot through to the tank?

response.answer_text: farming or fire, (not sure) Farming Before farming, humans were nomadic hunter gatherers. They may have been hungry and malnourished most of the the time, with short, miserable lives. If you are always hungry, your priorities are SurviveEatThat doesn't leave much time for contemplation, to plan, to organise. To communicate and cooperate (beyond hunting and gathering with your tribe). Population stays small. The world doesn't change. Fire Humans are the only creature that cooks food. Cooking makes food safer and makes more nutrients available to digest. Fire - not having fire - is a distinct advantage.

In various ages there have been various technological advances which most changed the world: the controlled use of fire, the wheel, the printing press, the steam engine, the use of electricity, the internal combustion engine, radio, the airplane, television, the computer, the cell phone. However if only one technological advance could be chosen as the one which most changed the world since the beginning of recorded history, then it would have to be the invention of writing.

One word -FIRE. It at one stroke gave us warmth and light. Gave us healthier, easier to digest food and gave us all the other technologies in the end. Starting with fire hardened wood spears and ending with H bombs. It also probably helped our intelligence to increase due to better food and better survival rates.

I can think of two that created similar advances, The use of electricity, particularly A/C, to provide lighting, motors, heating, communications and just about everything that uses electrical power. The other is the development of the internal combustion engine. While the steam engine started the artificial power revolution (not animal, wind or water) it was usually large and required skill to operate properly. The IC engine started the era of common mobility with cars, motorcycles, boats (not large ships though the diesel engine took over there) nad eventual airplanes.

In all of human history, actual written words have only been “invented” about 6 times in human history from what I have read. Most humans never progressed that far,, and their civilizations crumbled into dust. But when enough humans had invented writing, mankind literally came alive. The invention of movable type, roughly 400 years ado, was a huge accelerant to this process
